babyDevelopment: The embryo has implanted in your uterus. The neural tube, which becomes the brain and spinal cord, is forming. The placenta is beginning to develop to nourish your baby.
motherChanges: You may not know you're pregnant yet. Some women experience light spotting (implantation bleeding) or mild cramping. Your period should be due around now.
tips: Start taking prenatal vitamins with folic acid if you haven't already
Avoid alcohol, smoking, and limit caffeine
Schedule your first prenatal appointment

babyDevelopment: The heart begins to beat! It's tiny but pumping at about 100-160 beats per minute. The circulatory system is the first major system to function. Brain divides into 5 areas.
motherChanges: Pregnancy hormone hCG is rising rapidly. You may start experiencing morning sickness, breast tenderness, fatigue, and frequent urination. A missed period confirms pregnancy.
tips: Eat small, frequent meals to combat nausea
Stay well hydrated
Get plenty of rest when you can

babyDevelopment: Facial features are forming including dark spots for eyes and small openings for ears. The neural tube closes. Arm and leg buds are more defined. Heart has 4 chambers.
motherChanges: Morning sickness may intensify. You might notice mood swings, food aversions, and heightened sense of smell. Hormonal changes can cause skin changes.
tips: Identify and avoid your nausea triggers
Consider ginger tea or candies for morning sickness
Wear comfortable, supportive bras

babyDevelopment: The brain is growing rapidly—it grows about a third of its size! Arm buds look like paddles. Leg buds are forming. The beginnings of eyes' retinas are developing.
motherChanges: Fatigue and nausea may peak. You might experience increased saliva, bloating, and constipation. Emotions may fluctuate due to hormonal changes.
tips: Take short naps when needed
Eat protein-rich snacks to help with energy
Start thinking about prenatal testing options

babyDevelopment: All essential organs have begun to form. Baby makes tiny movements, though you can't feel them. Fingers are webbed but forming. Nose, lips, and eyelids becoming visible.
motherChanges: Your uterus is expanding to the size of a grapefruit. Frequent urination is common. Heartburn and indigestion may begin. Clothes may feel tighter.
tips: Avoid lying flat after meals to reduce heartburn
Consider a body pillow for sleeping comfort
Schedule your first ultrasound

babyDevelopment: Baby is now officially called a fetus! Eyes are fully formed but closed. Earlobes visible. Muscles developing, allowing small movements. All organs, muscles, and nerves functioning.
motherChanges: Your waistline may be thickening slightly. Mood swings and fatigue continue. Some women notice skin changes like darkening around nipples.
tips: Invest in comfortable, loose-fitting clothes
Stay active with gentle exercise like walking
Consider joining a pregnancy support group
milestones: Embryo is now called a fetus

babyDevelopment: All vital organs are formed and starting to function together. Fingernails and toenails developing. Baby can bend limbs at elbows and knees. Heartbeat detectable on Doppler.
motherChanges: Visible veins may appear on breasts and abdomen due to increased blood volume. Round ligament pain may begin. Growing uterus may cause slight abdominal cramping.
tips: Wear supportive, comfortable shoes
Continue moderate exercise if approved by your doctor
Discuss genetic testing options with your provider

babyDevelopment: Tooth buds appearing under gums. Baby can open and close hands, hiccup, and swallow amniotic fluid. External genitalia beginning to form. Head is about half the body size.
motherChanges: Morning sickness may start to ease for some. Hair and nails might grow faster. You may feel more energetic. Skin changes like linea nigra may appear.
tips: Eat calcium-rich foods for baby's developing bones
Start researching childcare and birthing options
Consider prenatal yoga classes

babyDevelopment: Reflexes developing—baby can curl toes and open/close fingers. Intestines in the abdomen now. Face has human profile. Fingernails formed. Kidneys making urine.
motherChanges: Risk of miscarriage drops significantly. Hormone levels stabilizing. You may feel more energetic. Belly might start showing, especially if not your first pregnancy.
tips: Many people share their news now
Start looking at maternity clothes
Schedule nuchal translucency screening if desired

babyDevelopment: Fingerprints are forming! Vocal cords developing. Baby can put thumb in mouth. Bones beginning to harden. Intestines making contractions to practice digestion.
motherChanges: End of first trimester. Energy typically increases. Morning sickness usually fading. Round ligament pain may increase as uterus grows.
tips: Celebrate reaching the second trimester!
Plan a babymoon if desired
Review your diet and exercise routine with your provider

babyDevelopment: Baby can squint, frown, and grimace. Kidneys producing urine released into amniotic fluid. Lanugo (fine downy hair) covers body. Neck is defined and lower limbs developed.
motherChanges: Welcome to the second trimester! Many women feel their best now. Round ligament pain common. Appetite may increase. Nasal congestion may begin.
tips: Enjoy the 'honeymoon phase' of pregnancy
Start sleeping on your side if comfortable
Begin planning the nursery

babyDevelopment: Bones hardening, especially long bones. Baby can sense light through closed eyelids. Scalp hair pattern established. Ears moving to final position on head.
motherChanges: Nasal congestion common due to increased blood flow. You might notice the pregnancy glow. Increased appetite. Round ligament stretching.
tips: Use a humidifier for nasal congestion
Start Kegel exercises to strengthen pelvic floor
Consider maternity photography planning

babyDevelopment: Facial muscles working—baby makes expressions. Nervous system connecting throughout body. Eyes moving slowly beneath closed lids. You might feel first movements (quickening).
motherChanges: Baby bump becoming more visible. Backaches may begin as center of gravity shifts. Some women feel first movements. Skin may feel itchy as it stretches.
tips: Practice good posture to reduce back pain
Stay active but don't overexert yourself
Schedule your anatomy scan (usually 18-20 weeks)

babyDevelopment: Skeleton changing from soft cartilage to bone. Fat stores beginning to form under skin. Sweat glands developing. Baby is more active with stronger movements.
motherChanges: Increased appetite is normal. Vivid dreams are common. Center of gravity continues shifting. You may feel off-balance at times.
tips: Eat iron-rich foods to support increased blood volume
Keep a dream journal if you find it interesting
Consider a pregnancy pillow for better sleep

babyDevelopment: Ears in final position on head. Baby may respond to loud sounds. Myelin coating nerves for faster signal transmission. Digestive system working.
motherChanges: Dizziness from blood pressure changes is common. Leg cramps may occur, especially at night. Increased vaginal discharge is normal.
tips: Stand up slowly to avoid dizziness
Stretch calves before bed to prevent cramps
Stay well hydrated throughout the day

babyDevelopment: Vernix caseosa (protective cheese-like coating) forms on skin. Sensory development is rapid. Baby has regular sleep/wake cycles. Arms and legs in proportion.
motherChanges: Hip pain may begin as ligaments loosen with relaxin hormone. Skin changes like linea nigra may darken. You may feel stronger movements.
tips: Try prenatal massage for hip and back pain
Use pregnancy-safe skincare products
Prepare questions for your anatomy scan

babyDevelopment: Halfway point! Baby can hear your voice and heartbeat. Meconium (first stool) forming in intestines. Hair may be growing on head. Anatomy scan can reveal sex.
motherChanges: Fundal height about equal to weeks pregnant. Belly button may pop out or flatten. Stronger, more distinct movements felt. Appetite may increase.
tips: Talk and sing to baby—they can hear you!
Take halfway celebration photos
Start researching birth plan options

babyDevelopment: Taste buds developing—baby can taste what you eat via amniotic fluid. Eyebrows and eyelids fully formed. Very active with lots of movement. Responds to touch.
motherChanges: Increased appetite continues. Spider veins or varicose veins may appear. Skin stretching may cause itching. You may feel baby respond to your touch.
tips: Elevate legs when resting to reduce swelling
Wear compression stockings if needed
Enjoy feeling baby move and respond to you

babyDevelopment: Grip strength increasing. Lips becoming more distinct. Eyes formed but iris lacks pigment. Fingernails fully formed. Baby may grasp the umbilical cord.
motherChanges: Braxton Hicks contractions may begin—irregular, painless tightening. Stretch marks might appear on belly, breasts, or thighs. Hemorrhoids possible.
tips: Learn to identify Braxton Hicks vs. real contractions
Moisturize skin to help with stretching
Start counting kicks to learn baby's patterns

babyDevelopment: Lungs developing surfactant essential for breathing after birth. REM sleep beginning—baby may dream! Hearing more refined. Recognizes your voice.
motherChanges: Swelling in feet and ankles common, especially late in day. Balance may be affected. Back pain may increase. Feeling more emotional.
tips: Elevate feet when sitting to reduce swelling
Avoid standing for long periods
Play music for baby to hear

babyDevelopment: Viability milestone—baby could potentially survive with intensive NICU care if born now. Inner ear fully developed for balance. Fingerprints and footprints complete.
motherChanges: Glucose screening test (for gestational diabetes) typically done now. Linea nigra may darken. Skin may be dry or itchy. You may feel out of breath at times.
tips: Complete your glucose screening test
Start researching pediatricians
Consider childbirth education classes

babyDevelopment: Baby responds to familiar voices with movement. Nostrils open and begin practicing breathing amniotic fluid. Spine straightening. Growing more hair.
motherChanges: Heartburn and indigestion common as uterus pushes stomach. Hemorrhoids may develop. Trouble finding comfortable sleeping positions. Frequent urination returns.
tips: Eat smaller, more frequent meals
Increase fiber intake to prevent constipation
Sleep propped up if heartburn bothers you

babyDevelopment: Eyes begin to open for the first time. Brain waves for hearing and sight are measurable. Lungs practicing breathing motions. Baby can distinguish light from dark.
motherChanges: Trouble sleeping is very common now. Braxton Hicks may become more noticeable. Lower back pain may intensify. You may feel pressure in pelvis.
tips: Establish a relaxing bedtime routine
Try relaxation techniques like deep breathing
Start packing your hospital bag soon

babyDevelopment: Brain tissue and neurons developing rapidly. Baby follows regular sleep/wake cycles you may notice. Hiccups common as baby practices breathing. May respond to your voice.
motherChanges: Leg cramps and restless legs may increase. Shortness of breath as uterus expands upward. You might feel baby hiccup—rhythmic movements.
tips: Stretch before bed to prevent leg cramps
Ask your doctor about magnesium supplements
Enjoy feeling baby's hiccups

babyDevelopment: Third trimester begins! Eyes can detect light and blink. Brain continues rapid development. Can dream during REM sleep. Weighs about 2.2 pounds.
motherChanges: Rh-negative mothers receive Rhogam shot. Shortness of breath as uterus expands. More frequent prenatal visits begin (every 2 weeks). Fatigue may return.
tips: Prenatal visits now every 2 weeks
Practice breathing exercises for labor
Finalize nursery preparations

babyDevelopment: Muscles and lungs maturing rapidly. Baby is more active with distinct rest and activity periods. Brain controlling body temperature. More fat forming under skin.
motherChanges: Fatigue returns as body works harder. Frequent urination increases. Braxton Hicks more regular. May experience shortness of breath and heartburn.
tips: Rest when you feel tired
Continue monitoring kick counts
Review and finalize your birth preferences

babyDevelopment: Brain surface becoming wrinkled (gyri and sulci forming) for more brain cells. Vision improving. Baby can follow a light source. May be head-down by now.
motherChanges: Mood swings may return. Difficulty finding comfortable positions. Baby may 'drop' lower in pelvis. Heartburn and indigestion common.
tips: Use multiple pillows for support when sleeping
Talk about your feelings with your partner
Tour the birthing center or hospital

babyDevelopment: All five senses are working together. Rapid brain development continues. Baby may turn head-down in preparation for birth. Can track light with eyes.
motherChanges: Leaky breasts (colostrum) may begin. Trouble catching breath as uterus presses diaphragm. Waddling walk develops as pelvis loosens. Frequent urination.
tips: Use nursing pads if breasts are leaking
Continue gentle exercise like walking or swimming
Finalize your birth plan details

babyDevelopment: Toenails visible. Skin becoming less transparent and more opaque. Baby gaining weight rapidly—about half a pound per week. Lanugo (body hair) disappearing.
motherChanges: Heartburn may worsen. Back pain common. Nesting instinct may kick in—urge to clean and organize. Braxton Hicks becoming more frequent.
tips: Avoid heavy meals before bed
Practice good posture throughout the day
Channel nesting energy productively

babyDevelopment: Bones hardening throughout body (except skull, which stays soft for delivery). Immune system developing. Baby can coordinate sucking and swallowing together.
motherChanges: Difficulty sleeping due to size and discomfort. Increased Braxton Hicks. May feel baby pressing on ribs. Shortness of breath common.
tips: Try sleeping in a semi-reclined position
Stretch gently to relieve discomfort
Install car seat and have it inspected

babyDevelopment: Central nervous system maturing. Lungs are almost fully developed. Vernix (protective coating) thickening. Baby's fingernails reach fingertips.
motherChanges: Fatigue intensifies. Vision changes possible (blurry vision). May experience carpal tunnel symptoms—numbness or tingling in hands. Swelling increases.
tips: Rest often—your body is working hard
Wear wrist splints if hands are numb
Prepare freezer meals for after baby arrives

babyDevelopment: Kidneys fully developed and functioning. Liver can process waste. Baby is running out of room—movements change to rolls and stretches instead of kicks.
motherChanges: Frequent urination increases as baby presses on bladder. Braxton Hicks more intense. Difficulty walking due to pelvic pressure. Insomnia common.
tips: Stay close to restrooms when out
Walk when comfortable to maintain mobility
Review hospital bag checklist

babyDevelopment: Baby may drop into pelvis (lightening). Fat continues accumulating for temperature regulation. Average weight about 6 pounds now. Most babies are head-down.
motherChanges: Breathing may be easier if baby drops. Increased pelvic pressure. Nesting urge very strong. Weekly prenatal visits begin. May lose mucus plug.
tips: Weekly prenatal visits start now
Keep your phone charged at all times
Rest as much as possible

babyDevelopment: Early term! Baby is practicing breathing movements. Head likely engaged in pelvis. Considered fully developed if born now. Gaining about an ounce per day.
motherChanges: Mucus plug may release (bloody show). Increased vaginal discharge. False labor (prodromal labor) common. Cervix may begin softening and dilating.
tips: Know the signs of true labor vs. false labor
Stay calm if you lose your mucus plug—can still be weeks
Continue gentle movement like walking

babyDevelopment: All organs are fully mature and functioning. Baby is gaining about 1 ounce per day. Meconium (first stool) present in intestines. Ready for life outside.
motherChanges: Cervix may begin dilating. Intense Braxton Hicks. Trouble sleeping due to discomfort and anticipation. Nesting instinct in full force.
tips: Rest as much as possible
Watch for bloody show (mucus with blood)
Pack any last-minute items for hospital

babyDevelopment: Full term! Chest is prominent. Baby is fully ready for birth. Average weight 7-8 pounds, 19-21 inches long. Lungs producing surfactant for breathing.
motherChanges: May feel burst of energy (nesting). Intense pelvic pressure. Possible diarrhea or loose stools before labor begins. Cervix ripening.
tips: Don't overdo it even with extra energy
Stay close to your hospital or birth center
Trust your body—you've got this

babyDevelopment: Due date! Average newborn is 19-21 inches and 7-8 pounds. Skull bones still soft and flexible to pass through birth canal. Baby is fully ready.
motherChanges: Waiting can be emotionally challenging. Cervical checks may be done. Baby could arrive any day. Some women experience prelabor symptoms.
tips: Be patient—only 5% of babies arrive on due date
Try natural comfort measures (walking, warm baths)
Enjoy these final days of pregnancy

babyDevelopment: Late term. Baby continues growing but may lose some vernix coating. Monitoring becomes more important to ensure baby is thriving. Placenta aging.
motherChanges: More frequent monitoring (non-stress tests, ultrasounds). Induction may be discussed. Emotionally and physically exhausting. Increased pressure.
tips: Stay in close contact with your healthcare provider
Discuss induction options and timing
Try to stay relaxed while waiting

babyDevelopment: Post-term. Baby's skin may be dry and peeling from reduced vernix. Placenta efficiency decreasing. Close monitoring essential for baby's wellbeing.
motherChanges: Induction usually scheduled by now. Continuous monitoring likely. Ready and anxious to meet your baby. May feel very uncomfortable.
tips: Follow your healthcare provider's guidance
Trust the medical team
You will meet your baby very soon!
